results.title: Everything you always wanted to know about supervision
results.brief_description: Highlights how a supervisor can develop skills to accomplish goals and objectives for the organisation and himself by mastering and consistently executing the fundamentals of supervision: organisation, delegation, communication, disclipine and motivation.

results.title: Every child a winner!
results.creator_credit: Charles F. Holbrook and American Alliance for Health, Physical Education, and Recreation
results.brief_description: Presents a case history of a program which demonstrates the values of individualised movement-based physical education, the Project Health and Optimum Physical Education program. Demonstrates the results of the program which concentrates on children at the elementary grade level. For teacher training.

results.title: Event horse
results.creator_credit: Robin Crane and Robin Crane Films
results.brief_description: Based on Sheila Willcox’s book “The Event horse”. Tells the story of the training of a “green” horse up to the winning of a novice horse trial. Training technicalities are presented in an interesting way, and the whole story of training and competing is designed to give people a better understanding of the purpose and requirements of a horse trial.
results.description: Based on Sheila Willcox’s book “The Event horse”. Tells the story of the training of a “green” horse up to the winning of a novice horse trial. Training technicalities are presented in an interesting way, and the whole story of training and competing is designed to give people a better understanding of the purpose and requirements of a horse trial.

results.title: Evaluation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Depicts a school that takes its evaluation seriously. Keeping in touch with its community has required constant monitoring and some innovative adjustments. Staff, curriculum, in service and Supplementary Grants meetings are now one and the same and are occasions where parents and teachers learn together.

results.title: Why Not the Kids?
results.creator_credit: Chelsea Productions and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program of Victoria and shows how children can participate in school organisation. Children at a Victorian Primary School formed a committee and applied for and were granted a Supplementary Grant. The children suggested changes in school facilities, organisation and even curricula. In doing so, some of changes that occured challenged teachers’ perceptions of students and caused them to reappraise their role in the school community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chelsea Productions and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development

results.title: Red Tape
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Changes…From the Inside”.
Devised by Glenn and Les Mack for the Supplementary Grants Program and shows a school community breaking down barriers to encourage community involvement in school decision making. The school draws its pupils from a housing commission estate and the principal’s aim is to create a school that responds to the community rather than the conventional process of making the commnity respond to the bureaucratic needs of the school.

results.title: The Importance of listening
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall, Educational Research and Development and Teacher Education and Far West Laboratory
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”.
If a discussion is to be useful it is essential to listen. The onus to keep the discussion going is on both the moderator and the participants. The moderator should: Summarise ideas and restore issues. The participants should: Listen to the other person’s ideas, acknowledge others’ ideas, question relevance. The case represented in this film is a discussion between black and white high school students and a white policeman concerning a fatal police shooting of a black man. The film uses this topic to illustrate skills of keeping a discussion on track (as a mediator) and relating participants’ comments and questions to each other.

results.title: Understanding different points of view
results.creator_credit: Richard Murison, Barbara Dunning, Meredith D. Gall and Far West Laboratory for Educational Research and Development
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Discussing Controversial Issues”
Explains that to provide good discussion and to understand other points of view the participants should: give reasons, ask for reasons and ask for clarification; while the Moderator should: ask for reasons, state areas of agreement and disagreement and ask for temporary agreement.
